newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria to receive 100,000 T of Polish wheat.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria to receive 100,000 T of Polish wheat.

text.p: Bulgaria will receive 100,000 tonnes of wheat from Poland, probably in exchange for future exports, as a result of President Petar Stoyanov's visit to Warsaw, the Bulgarian presidency said on Thursday.
"As a consequence of the visit, Poland has decided to grant Bulgaria 100,000 tonnes of wheat, which will help to ease the country's acute grain shortage," a presidency spokesman said.
Details of the deal were yet to be decided, but there was an agreement that Bulgaria would export the same quantity of wheat from the new crop.
Bulgaria is suffering a severe wheat shortage after uncontrolled exports two years ago depleted supplies. A poor harvest last year was attributed to bad weather and a lack of funds for fertilisers.

Earler this week the interim government unblocked 21,400 tonnes of wheat from the state reserves, but agricultural ministry officials said the country would need 450,000 tonnes of wheat to fill the gap until the new crop.

Bulgaria has sealed a deal with Argentina for 130,000 tonnes of grain, and is negotiating an agreement under the U.S. Department of Agriculture's GSM-102 export credit guarantee programme for 130,000-150,000 tonnes from the United States.
